details.description: Assam is a bold, malty black tea known for its rich flavor and dark liquor, often used in breakfast blends.
details.origin: Grown in the Assam region of India, this tea thrives in the region's tropical climate.
details.harvest_notes: Assam tea is typically harvested twice a year, during the first flush (spring) and second flush (summer).
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Assam tea in water heated to 95°C-100°C (203°F-212°F) for 3-5 minutes for a robust cup.
details.health_benefits: High in antioxidants, Assam tea is believed to support heart health and boost energy.
details.popularity: Widely popular for its strong, malty flavor, often enjoyed with milk and sugar.

details.description: Ceylon tea is a versatile black tea with a bright, citrusy flavor and medium body.
details.origin: Grown in Sri Lanka, the flavor profile varies based on the altitude of cultivation.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested year-round, with higher altitudes producing lighter teas and lower altitudes yielding bolder flavors.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Ceylon tea in water heated to 95°C-100°C (203°F-212°F) for 3-5 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Rich in antioxidants, it may support immune function and enhance metabolism.
details.popularity: Popular globally as a standalone tea or as a base for blends like Earl Grey.

details.description: Darjeeling is a light, floral black tea often referred to as the 'Champagne of Teas.'
details.origin: Grown in the Darjeeling district of West Bengal, India, at high altitudes.
details.harvest_notes: Typically harvested in three flushes: first flush (spring), second flush (summer), and autumn flush.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Darjeeling in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 2-3 minutes for a delicate brew.
details.health_benefits: Contains antioxidants that may help combat stress and promote healthy digestion.
details.popularity: Highly prized for its unique muscatel flavor and light body.

details.description: Dian Hong is a premium Chinese black tea with a sweet, malty flavor and golden tips.
details.origin: Produced in Yunnan Province, China, Dian Hong is known for its high-quality leaves.
details.harvest_notes: Crafted from tender, golden buds and leaves, often handpicked during early spring.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Dian Hong in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Rich in flavonoids, it may support cardiovascular health and improve mental alertness.
details.popularity: Beloved for its smooth taste and sweet, honey-like aroma.

details.description: Hong Yu, or Ruby Black Tea, is a rare Taiwanese tea with a rich, fruity flavor and hints of mint and cinnamon.
details.origin: Grown in the Sun Moon Lake region of Taiwan, this tea is made from a hybrid tea plant.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested from summer to autumn, with leaves handpicked for quality.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Hong Yu in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Known for its calming properties and potential to reduce inflammation.
details.popularity: Highly sought after for its complex flavor profile and rarity.

details.description: Jin Jun Mei is an exquisite Chinese black tea with a sweet, caramel-like flavor and golden-hued leaves.
details.origin: Grown in Wuyi Mountains, Fujian Province, China, known for its small-batch production.
details.harvest_notes: Crafted from young buds, picked in early spring and carefully processed by hand.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Jin Jun Mei in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 2-3 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Believed to promote relaxation and enhance focus.
details.popularity: Highly regarded for its luxury status and exceptional taste.

details.description: Jiu Qu Hong Mei, or Red Plum, is a sweet and fruity black tea from China.
details.origin: Grown in the Jiuqu district of Zhejiang Province, known for its delicate processing.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested in spring and summer, using tender leaves for a refined flavor.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Jiu Qu Hong Mei in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: May support digestion and provide a gentle energy boost.
details.popularity: Appreciated for its fruity and floral notes, making it a favorite among tea lovers.

details.description: Keemun is a classic Chinese black tea with a smooth, wine-like flavor and a hint of smokiness.
details.origin: Produced in Qimen County, Anhui Province, China, renowned for its high-quality black teas.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested in early spring, with leaves carefully rolled and oxidized for flavor.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Keemun in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Known to support mental alertness and relaxation.
details.popularity: A staple in traditional English breakfast blends.

details.description: Mi Zhuan, or Honey Aroma Tea, is a sweet, mellow black tea with a honey-like fragrance.
details.origin: Grown in Yunnan Province, China, this tea is prized for its unique aroma.
details.harvest_notes: Crafted from leaves with a natural honey-like taste, harvested in late spring.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Mi Zhuan in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: May support digestion and provide calming effects.
details.popularity: Loved for its natural sweetness and smooth finish.

details.description: Xiao Chi Gan, or Small Red Sweet Tea, is a mild, sweet black tea with a smooth, subtle flavor.
details.origin: Produced in Fujian Province, China, known for its high-quality teas.
details.harvest_notes: Made from small leaves, picked in late spring for a delicate profile.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Xiao Chi Gan in water heated to 90°C-95°C (194°F-203°F) for 3-4 minutes.
details.health_benefits: May help relax the mind and improve digestion.
details.popularity: Appreciated for its gentle sweetness and versatility.

details.description: Zheng Shan Xiao Zhong, or Lapsang Souchong, is a smoky black tea with a bold, pinewood aroma.
details.origin: Grown in Wuyi Mountains, Fujian Province, China, known as the birthplace of black tea.
details.harvest_notes: Made from larger leaves and traditionally smoked over pinewood fires.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Zheng Shan Xiao Zhong in water heated to 95°C-100°C (203°F-212°F) for 4-5 minutes.
details.health_benefits: Rich in antioxidants, it may boost metabolism and support respiratory health.
details.popularity: Renowned for its smoky flavor and robust character.
